Comment: The Caro-Kann, a relatively new defense at the time.
The Caro-Kann, a relatively new defense at the time.
Instead of setting up an ideal center with P-Q4, Lasker first develops a Knight.
Without Lasker's QP in the center, this move threatens to seize it for Black.
Lasker keeps developing. Now if Black exchanges Pawns...
...which he does...
...Lasker has a beautifully centralized Knight.
Black attempts to drive Lasker's Knight from is central post.
Instead of moving back to QB3, Lasker counterattacks Black's Bishop.
The other choice, keeping the B on its original diagonal, was 5... B-Q2.
Lasker plots a K-side attack.
Black creates a retreat for the B and guards against 7 N-N5.
With N-N5 impossible, Lasker chooses this square instead.
The B retreats into the hidey-hole.
Lasker focuses attention on the natural weakness at KB7.
The only defense.
Pressuring KB7 again. Now 9... PxQ??? 10 BxP mate!
Cutting off another diagonal and creating a flight square at K2.
With the Queen out of danger, Lasker now threatens down the K file.
Trying to chase the Knight. But...
Forking Q and R. If 11... KxN, 12 QxP ch K-B1 13 Q-B7 mate. So Black resigns.
